content:
And Richard and James
enjoy life under canvas.

Good evening.
Now, back in the late '60s,

Nissan or Datsun,
as they were called back then,
decided to make a sports car.
This is it, the 240Z.
It was a very simple recipe.

Three parts E-type Jaguar,
two parts Corvette,

and a sprinkling
of Japanese reliability.
Fabulous car!

But unfortunately
they kept changing it,

and each time they
changed it, they made it
a little bit worse.

There was the 260Z,
which was plump,
the 280Z, which was...
John Prescott.

And then finally, they ended
up with this enormous thing,
the 300ZX.
Marlon Brando, really.
The horror.
The horror.

And I believe
we've been joined here

by some people from
the Nissan Z Club, yes?

- Yes.
- Which is yours?
The 280.

And what in the name
of all that's holy

possessed you
to buy that?

I bought it 15 years ago,
and it looked good then.
It didn't look good!
It's beige with red seats!

- Are you from Birmingham?
- Yes, how did you guess?
That explains it all!

- Have you got one as well?
- I have, yeah.
And you've got a beard.

- And you're from the Z club?
- Yes, indeed.

And you have a beard. There,
that explains the appeal of the Z car!

Happily, however,
Nissan has now gone

back to basics
with the 350Z.

And I was so keen
to give this a go

that when the very first one
arrived in Britain months ago,

I grabbed the keys
and went for a drive.

Part of the reason
why Nissan's Z cars

became so fat and so
heavy over the years

is that they were designed
principally for the American market.

And the ideal American
car is, as I'm sure you know,
is an enormous sofa.

This one however wasn't just
designed for the Americans,

it was designed in
America, in California.

Home of the palm-fringed,
no smoking, six-lane boulevard.

And that's great, except we
don't have any of that here.
What we have is Sheffield.

So, how does the surfer boy
go down in the steel town?

Well, to be honest, I think
it looks a bit of a mess.
But then, it would.

Because it's a Japanese
car designed in America.

And the head
of the whole project

was a chap
called Ajay Panchal,

who's an Indian
from Leicester.

And the engine?
Well, that's French.

Incongruously, it's the 3.5 litre
V6 from the Renault Vel Satis.
We've had fusion food before,

but this is the first time
that I've ever encountered
a fusion car.

Think of it as being
a raw hamburger curry
served in a disinterested way
on a bed of garlicky jus.

Not that you can concentrate on
the ingredients because of the stereo.

You don't hear it
so much as feel it,

pulsating through an enormous
subwoofer in the small of your back.

If you're the sort of
person who likes to

cruise the streets, annoying
everyone with your drum 'n' bass,

this is definitely
the car for you.

I'm afraid, however, I'm more
interested in how a car goes.

So, I pointed
its nose at the road

which snakes out of Sheffield
and up onto the moors.

It doesn't take
very long to work out

that this car has
a few weak links.

And the biggest,
weakest link of them all

is the French bit,
the engine.

First of all,
there's the noise,
which is just a noise,

a sort of wearisome
drone. Listen.
It just gets on your nerves.

And then there's
the performance.

They say it will do
0-60 in six seconds,

and on to
a top speed of 150.
And I'm sure it will.

But it never really feels
that fast, somehow.
There's something else, too.
When you look at the 350Z,

you think it's gonna be
light and agile and sporty.

I was expecting it to be
like a Nikon camera,

all kind of
delicate and clever.

I thought it'd be like a Mazda
MX5, but with more power.
And it just isn't.
Not even slightly.

What it is, is a tonne and
a half of iron mongering.
It's a muscle car.

Which should be good fun
on a road like this.

I could go very,
very berserk at this point,

but two things
are stopping me.

One, the noise.
It's driving me mad.

And secondly,
it was on this very road

that the drummer with a
band called Def Leppard

crashed his muscle car,
a Corvette.
And as a result of that

he now has to drive with a
knob on his steering wheel.

I also have to say that
after a day behind the wheel,
I am knackered.

A hard ride and
the effort of driving it

makes it one of the most
exhausting cars I've ever come across.

And I haven't finished
mauling it yet either.

The look of
the interior is fine.

I've got a big rev counter
right in front me,

three ancillary
dials over here,
driving position's good.

But what's not
so good is this.

I've seen better build quality
on an allotment shed.

Now let's talk
about practicality.

There isn't any.
It has no back seats at all,

just a sort of bulkhead to which all
the various speakers are attached.

And if we
open the boot,

we find an enormous
strengthening beam

where your dog
would normally go.

All things considered, then,
the 350 is a C minus.
Three out of 10.
Could do better.

- So, no good then?
- Not really.

And the thing is, there's no
shortage of sports coupes coming up.

There's the Mazda RX8
which is very nice.

- Yeah. Wankel rotary engine.
- Very good engine.

Audi TT, they're putting a V6 in
that with a clever gearbox thing.

There's the
Chrysler Crossfire.

That's a Mercedes SLK with
an American body on it, yeah.

The point being, it's not exactly
got the feel to itself, has it?

Well, no.
But the thing is that.
Nissan have now said, "Aha!"

But the car you drove
was sort of for,

I don't know,
a small market

in the south of France
or somewhere.

The British ones,
which are going on sale in...

- About, September-October.
- Yes, September-October.

Are going to have better
suspension, bigger fuel tank,

different aero-dynamics,
better interior trim,

and a traction controller stand.
Could be completely different.

Which rather
begs the question...

Why didn't they say, "There's
our new car. See what you think.

"It won't be anything like that
obviously, but there it is anyway."

Nevertheless,
we'll give them...

I think we'll give them
the benefit of the doubt.

We'll hope the
British ones are better

and then when
we get a British one,

then we'll give it
to the Stig.
Right. Time for the news.

Now, it's a terrible shame,
uh, Jeremy didn't like the 350Z.

I wondered if you might be
interested in the 350Z watch.

It's a very large watch
with a very small face.

What do you
think of that?

It'll probably go...
Tick-tock!

"Tick-tock!"
And be very heavy.

You'll have to be like this
all day long with it.

BMW. The X5 is a very
nice car. There's now the X3.
Not a very nice car.

Well, a lot of people like
it an awful lot. There it is.

That's the X3.
You can see the kind of
3 Series BMW look to it.

This is going to be
launched, um, very shortly.
And I can't find...

Well, it'll be seen in
September, launched next year.

I can't tell you exactly
how much it's going to cost.

All BMW will say is it'll
cost less than the X5.

- Well, it better had, really. 'Cause it's the X3.
- Well, it's smaller.

And it's gonna have a three litre
petrol engine, three litre diesel engine.

And that's about all
we know at the moment.

That's Iceland,
that is.

- Is it?
- Yeah.

And I'll tell you why
it's driving on the road.

An X5, if you move it even onto
the pebbles at the side of the road,
it'll get stuck.
And that'll be worse.
Yeah. Bit of damp grass.

But I'll tell you
one thing, the X5,

the bigger one, right?
Classic drug dealer car.

- Blacked-out windows, big alloys.
- Yeah.

- Yeah.
- Well, it is!

- They're the only people who buy 'em.
- Yeah.

The X3 is gonna be
perfect if you're,
you know, small-time.

- Maybe just sell to your friends.
- Yeah.
It's the perfect car.

It's a small
drug dealer's car.
Or sell glue.

Yeah,
you could sell glue out the...

I love the way
they always do this.

When they get a new
off-road car like that,

they always,
always, always...

They say, "Oh right. Let's
go somewhere really rugged."

Look where they've gone!
It's a mildly gravelled road.

Comepletely level.
I'll tell you what.
It'll be absolutely useless.

Really, I guarantee
that car will be useless.

Right.
John Prescott update.
He's bought another Jaguar.

- All right.
- But...
He's bought an old...

He walked into a shop and
went down a row of jackets.
"This one, I think."
Hmm, perfect.

Interesting thing is, he's sold
one of his previous Jaguars.
And he's been joking,

it says here,
with newpaper reporters,

"Ha! You can't call me
John 'Three Jags' Prescott."

- So what shall we call him?
- They can still call him a fat Welshman, though.
There you go.

Poor people
at Jaguar, though.

"No, don't buy
another, John, please.

"And don't be photographed,
standing next to it like that."

- Did you know he was Welsh?
- Is he really?

Yeah. He pretends
to be from Yorkshire,

but I'm from Yorkshire
and I can spot a fraud.

In the last programme we were
talking about crashing and what happens.

And those
NCAP crash tests.

And remember
we crashed a Megane?
Sorry, Renault!

This is the Espace,
the new one.

And they've
done it again

because this has
actually been through...

Just put through those
NCAP crash tests,

in which they crash into a barrier
and assess how well it does.

And it's got,
not only five stars,

it's got the highest points
ever in the crash test.

You've got to
hand it to Renault.

They're taking this
very seriously.

So that's the safest car
they've ever tested?

According to those
crash tests, yeah.

That is the safest thing
they've ever tested.

Still gotta have a people
carrier, though, haven't we?

You have. But the interesting
point is that's a big car.

It did well. Now we also
saw on that programme

that small cars like the Ford
Fiesta, they can do well, too.

You started saying,
"Oh, well, big's best."

- The bigger the car...
- Size is better.
Big is better than little.
In every way.
Isn't it, girls?

Every week we end
up in the same territory.

But you started going on
about the Hummer.

"That's very safe 'cause
it's as big as a house.

"Really, really safe car
if you crash it."
Apparently not.

Here is one
that's been crashed
and that doesn't look...

That's run into
an American's buttock.
I spilt my burger!

He's dropped his
Styrofoam... "Oh, hell!"

"Oh, hell, I've gone
and run into my wife.

"One of her cheeks has done
that to the front of my car."
That's a mess.
Now, listen.

Have you seen they've announced
now that we're not allowed to use

our mobiles phones
while driving
as of December 1st.

- Yeah.
- Why not?

What possible reason is there for you
not to being able to use your mobile?

If you've got one hand and
you're talking on your phone.

Are they saying that
one-handed people can't drive?

- Really?
- That's true, that's not right.

I'm sorry, that's just not
fair on disabled people.

You know, there's plenty of
people who've got one-arm

who can drive
perfectly well.

If they say
it's the talking...

But you talk
to your passenger

and you talk to
kids in the back.
I just don't...

This is just
government meddling.

If you have only
got one arm, though,

don't try using
the telephone and driving.

You're gonna need
a hands-free.
You could use your knees.

I often drive using
my... But it is.

It's like they've gone
for the mobile phone,

but actually, the amount of
distractions this time of year,

hay fever
for instance.

If you sneeze
at 70mph, you're blind,

we worked this out,
for 210 feet.

Have you tried driving
with your eyes shut?

And they don't say you're
not allowed to drive with hay...
Or worse, worse.

Have you ever driven when
you need to go to the loo?
That's the worst!
Get out of the way!

Get out of the way!
It's roadworks!
I've got to do 210!

And you go skidding into
that motorway service area

and into the
disabled parking spot.

I don't care,
I'm going to burst!

There's the RAC patrolman.
"Would you like to join?"

"No. Would you like
a golden shower, mate?"
The ladies is nearer.
I am absolutely lethal!

But I've never seen
anybody charged with

driving while
they're full bladder.

Do you know what is
the most dangerous thing

you can do
when driving a car?

- What?
- Have a takeaway curry on the passenger seat.

It's another of
James' theories.

- So I'll tell you why.
- Yeah.

You will not brake for
anything. I've done this.

- You're right!
- I am right, I know.

This is a true story,
and I am ashamed of it.

I was driving along.
Ford Galaxy, Magnolia Leather.

Curry on the
passenger seat.

A drunk bloke
walked into the road.
Instinctively, I braked.

I saw the curry tip,
I thought that's my dinner.

I not only took my foot off the
break, I put it back on the throttle.

Anyway, if anybody
here's interested,

I've developed a special new car
sticker that says "Bhuna On Board".
That's enough curry.

Now, did you know that the
British buy more convertibles than

the French, the Italians
and the Spanish put together.

We were absolutely amazed
at this, and what's more...

There's a whole raft of
new ones out this year,

so me and Hammond here,
we thought we'd take

a selection of them on a
typical British summer holiday.

This is Buttermere.
The wettest place in Britain.

And this is the campsite at
the wettest place in Britain.

And we're staying here
tonight because we're British.
Right, it's the morning.

I'm going to take
a look outside the tent.
Now, if it's raining,

foreigners are going to
roll about laughing at us.

But if it's sunny,
even if it's just dry,

they will never know
how good we feel.
It's dry!

And that is just one of the
reasons why we love these cars.

It's that crazy
British optimism.

Because you never know,
any day, summer or winter,

you might just get to
drive it with the top down.
This is the new VW Beetle.

We've waited years
for this to arrive.

And from some angles
it does look a bit classic.

I mean, look at that
roof folded down there.

Looks like somebody's
glued a lilo to the boot.
Morning.

Now, you can buy a Beetle
Cabriolet for 15,400 quid.
But that's for the 1.6.

This is the two-litre engine
version which is 17,500.

And that's about
17,500 too much.

It looks cute now
but it's a fashion statement

that'll be out of fashion
very soon.

It might've been saved
if it was good to drive.
But it's not that either.

Its only virtues
are four good seats

and the fact
that it's German.

This does feel
very well put together,

you can't deny that.
It's really, really solid.

And I like the plastics.
They're nice.

I like the body colour repeat
panel on top of the door.

All they got to do
is make it in the shape

of a proper car
and it'd be terrific.

Here we are,
driving into the rain.

Which in some ways
is beneficial.

People tell you
this in the pub.

All the time you take the top off your
convertible car, you drive it in the rain,

you get above a certain speed
and you're fine, you don't get wet.

It's rubbish.
I'm soaked.

I'm not sure
this was such a smart idea.

Why? You just think
we're a pair of extremely...

- Well, exactly.
- Yes.

Gonna have to
put the roof up!
Stop!

- What happened?
- I've had enough!

I just got squall
in my face!

What we want in Britain is a
convertible car for sunny days

and a hardtop
for the other 364.

Which is why we like
folding metal roofs.

This is the smallest
and most ingenious yet.

The Daihatsu Copen.
It's so ingenious

we might not notice that this
toy car costs almost £13,000.

The ride's a bit
rock hard on this thing,

but apart from that
it's really rather good.

It's got red leather seats
and a Momo steering wheel.

The engine goes
to 8,500 revs

and there's a really nice cold
metal ball on top of the gear stick.

So what we have is
a sort of Sony Ferrari.

Same sort of thing,
but much smaller.

660cc's and a turbocharger.
It's brilliant!
The new Audi A4,

the benchmark
four-seater cabriolet.

Normally, the A4 Cabriolet
is a fabulously discrete car.
But in this case,

they've spoilled it by painting it
in a colour called Cosmic Yellow,

which is also known
as Premium Beige.

Right, now it's not just the
colour that lets this car down.

'Cause here we go. We're
in the country. This is nice.

- Gentle tweeting of birds.
- Slight breeze.

See the
undergrowth over there?

Let's have
another country sound.
Ah, yes, Massey Ferguson.

It's a diesel!
Somebody decided,

"Let's make a discreetly
glamorous 4-seater cabriolet

"and equip it
with a tractor's engine."

It is a good
diesel engine.

Well, in truth, it's a
fantastic diesel engine.

And, actually,
it's not that noisy, is it?

No, it's not.
Not on the move.

But when
you're going slow,

or you're just
creeping through town,

or more significantly, just
pulling up outside a nice bar.
Yeah.

People are going to say,
"That's nice, where's the taxi?"

No,
it's just not right.

A diesel cabriolet is like
a supermodel smoking a pipe.

Audi should've stuck
with the formula,

like Mercedes have
with their new CLK.

This one, for
example, has a big,

extravagant and completely
illogical five-litre V8.

By the Audi A4,
this Mercedes CLK convertible

dwells deep in the heartland
of the posh German car.
But there's a difference.

This one's wearing
a huge Rolex!

It wants you know
it was really expensive.

Prices start at £30,000,
which is where the A4s stop.
This one cost 58,000.

Smaller Mercedes convertibles have
metal folding roofs, the SL and the SLK.

This one has got
a canvas one.

Because, well, a four-seater
folding roof just wouldn't fit in the boot.
But what a canvas roof!

I mean, compared
with our tent!

280 components
just in the roof frame!
And a lightning conductor.

So, you see,
Jerry does care about us!

So, a cabriolet can be big or
small, flash or a shrinking violet.

Or maybe it can be
nearly all those things.

Citroen reckons
it's new Pluriel

can be anything
you want it to be.
This is the convertible stage.

- That's the convertible?
- Yeah.
Oh, no!
Yeah, that's it!
That...
Cabriolet.
Where are the flaps?

They're not under
the floor bed, are they?
No.

- Are you sure they're not under the floor bed?
- No.
Bit like that.
Oh, I see.

- You have to... No.
- Yeah I'm... I'm doing it!
Try that.
Miles out!
That's the Spider.
Shut the door.
Do we look good with it?

Being French, most
of the trim will drop off,

but what's underneath
is pretty tough.

It costs from 12 to
13 and a half thousand

and you can have
a 1.4 or a 1.6 engine.

But if you go for the 1.6, you have
to have the flappy paddle gearshift.
And it's hopeless.

I'm changing gear. I'm gonna put it
in second to go around this corner.

That's okay. Now I'm
gonna wait for third...
And now it's changed.

I'm gonna
select fourth... No.
Oh, now I've got it.

What? Have you got
something else on?
And there's another problem.
We're going left.

Citroen has the belief that

to drive it with the roof rails
in place. Well, I can see why.

- Yeah, because it really...
- It's in place or in your crotch.
So, is it going to rain, then?
Yeah, almost certainly.
Mmm. I brought the roof.

Just to be on
the safe side.

So, judging

you didn't much
go for the Pluriel.

No. It's a shame,

kind of, cutesie looking,

and it is clever with all that

The roof is such a faff,
drive you mad.
Excellent hire car.

- 'Cause then you can give it back.

And that gearbox, it's...
Drive you mad.

I'm told it's
quite safe, though.

It's very safe.
It did very well.
NCAP crash-test, four stars.

Which is about the safest

That was with
the roof rails off.

So, it's a four

The thing that worries me most

- Yes.

There's nothing in it at all!
Has it got an engine?

The Daihatsu Copen,

It's fantastic.

You're not gonna

it's small, it's silly.

- No.
- All right.

But I'm sure it happened,

Okay, well,
it's a bit like that.

You sort of drive around amongst

It's absolutely brilliant.

Can't say I noticed it myself. I

Beetle. Would you

- Nope.
- No.

- Nah, you're gonna look sick.
- You would?

You'd buy one? Hang on a

Very stylish, very cute.
Everyday car term.

Hitler designed it.

You like something

Great, um...
Pluriel we've done.

What about this finished in
lovely baby diarrhoea here?

In any other colour, that is a

It really is
the business. Yeah.

to be a very, very good car.

What about the Mercedes?
Would you buy one of those?

Possibly,
but not with that engine.

That's the 500 V8.
I don't know about you,

I sort of think,

you either have a performance

So, you may as well
have the little engine.

- You might as well.
- If you have the little engine,

why have that?
Why not have the Audi?

I was about say, you might

I can't see why you'd take the

So, of all of them,
which do you like the most?
Audi, Copen.

So, we've basically decided

- Yeah, excellent.
But I can't drive that Copen!

You would look

I hope you do one day.
I'd love to see it.

I've got to try this out. I'm

I gotta see that.

It's not so much
a car as a shoe.

Oh, look at that,
that's fantastic!
Do you know the really...

Do you know
the really funny thing

is that if I did more

I'd end up with hair
like this guy, look!
Look at this!
You came in a Copen!

Oh, dear.
I don't know.

I think you should just
work harder and buy an SL.
Well, there we are.

Now, my guest tonight
is very, very tall
and a global fashion icon.
Kind of like me, really.

Ladies and gentlemen,
supermodel Jodie Kidd!
Now, look.

This is what we've
been waiting for, really.

- Have a sit down.
- God, I can't tell you how nice it is

to have someone on the show
who's a proper size.

I know, I don't have to
look down the whole time.

No, exactly.
But what about cars?

Do you have trouble
getting in them?

I do indeed actually,
but, um...

Yeah, I'm quite
nimble. I can fit in.

You know,
I'm not that big.
Big, you know. I'm tall.

No, 'cause there is... I mean, I
have a rule I basically always say,

"I can get into anything
I want to get into."

- Yes, that does help.
- If it's a Ferrari...
That does help.

I don't mind driving
with my knees up here.

Exactly, I always found that
with knees around your elbows.

Actually, for you,
that might... Yeah.
Um, now.

You were recently described in the
Birmingham Evening Post as being...
I've got it written down here.

"A self-indulgent celebrity
setting a really bad example."
Great. I'm really happy.

That's exactly
what I want to be.

- Did you know that?
- The Birmingham Post?

This was about, apparently,
you going on the Gumball rally.
I think that's a great idea.

The Gumball, yeah, no.
It's fantastic.
